info.game_comments:
2001 Tournament of Champions semifinal game 2.

(Sarah: This is Sarah of the Clue Crew with a friend in from the Arctic.  Bear with us! Jeopardy!'s next!)

(1, 1).clue: This one of the simple machines can be made by using a wheel & a rope

(2, 1).clue: He played fictional hero Perry Mason off & on from 1957 until his death in 1993

(3, 1).clue: He lost the presidency by a 71-68 electoral vote count, so he settled for the VP slot in 1796

(4, 1).clue: In hunting, dogs might chase their quarry up a tree, sometimes the dogs didn't choose the right tree

(5, 1).clue: It's the term for a type of French bread baked into a long, cylindrical loaf with a crisp crust & a chewy inside

(6, 1).clue: The tattered, unshaven hobo type of this performer caught on in American circuses

(1, 2).clue: Manufacturers of fireworks use barium to give off a green color & sodium to produce this color

(2, 2).clue: Christopher Plummer narrated a 1993 Family Channel series about this Paris schoolgirl

(3, 2).clue: Speaking at Columbia Law School's 2000 commencement, he joked that he invented Lexis-Nexis

(4, 2).clue: Sometimes a flintlock musket's fuse, called a pan, would flare up without firing the gun

(5, 2).clue: Sourdough bread uses a special yeast one of these as the leavener

(6, 2).clue: In the 1880s, circus owner Adam Forepaugh tried to compete with P.T. Barnum, who had this elephant as an attraction

(1, 3).clue: Inhaling & exhaling result from the contraction of this muscle at the floor of the chest cavity

(2, 3).clue: Pamela Sue Martin, who played this sleuth, left her show when it was merged with the Hardy Boys'

(3, 3).clue: He found the press quite taxing, calling them "Nattering nabobs of negativism"

(4, 3).clue: On early warships, sailors & their wives slept between the cannons; the wives gave birth there as well

(5, 3).clue: Pumpernickel often gets its flavor from this brownish-black liquid made when sugar is refined

(6, 3).clue: The Cristiani Brothers Circus specialized in this equestrian style that didn't saddle them with extra props

(1, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew is at Sea World in San Diego.)  In the wild, the polar bear feeds mainly on these, especially the ringed species

(2, 4).clue: In 1979 this James Jones novel was a miniseries with Steve Railsback in Montgomery Clift's movie role

(3, 4).clue: He only served 6 months as VP before he took the presidential oath of office in Buffalo

(4, 4).clue: Deciphering hidden writing within a paragraph that couldn't be seen unless the paper was treated

(5, 4).clue: It's the German word for rusk, bread that is baked twice to make it crisp

(6, 4).clue: Franco Knie, manager & elephant trainer of Circus Knie, has been romancing this Monaco princess

(1, 5).clue: The elements erbium, terbium, ytterbium & yttrium are named for the town of Ytterby in this country

(2, 5).clue: This 1994 miniseries based on a Stephen King book depicts the aftermath of a devastating plague

(3, 5).clue: This ex-VP took the presidential oath of office from Judge Sarah Hughes, the first woman to administer it

(4, 5).clue: A boxing technique where you move away so you won't feel the full force when a punch lands

(5, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew dines on bread.)  I'm braiding this bread that's blessed & served at certain Friday night dinners

(6, 5).clue: A circus formed in the 1930s combined the names of the Cole Brothers & this famous circus figure seen here

(1, 1).clue: Jesus said to him, "Betrayest thou the Son of Man with a kiss?"

(2, 1).clue: 1 magnum of champagne equals this many standard bottles

(4, 1).clue: This wonderful, wonderful city is home to the world-famous Tivoli Gardens

(5, 1).clue: Because Bernardo Strozzi had been a Capuchin friar, he was nicknamed this, which sounds like an Italian coffee drink

(6, 1).clue: '40s bandleader playing "In the Mood" who drinks a less filling beer before charging "In the valley of death"

(1, 2).clue: This angel announced the coming births of both Jesus & John the Baptist

(2, 2).clue: At the Olympics, a 437.6 yard run equals this many meters

(3, 2).clue: She's the glamorous lead singer seen here

(4, 2).clue: It lies at the mouth of the River Liffey

(5, 2).clue: Luca Giordano was nicknamed "Luca Fa Presto" because he worked this way

(6, 2).clue: A black female 1920s entertainer living near Sherlock Holmes would have this type of urban shrewdness

(1, 3).clue: In Mark 4:39 Jesus calmed this body of water by saying, "Peace. Be still"

(2, 3).clue: Traveling approximately 1,500 miles per hour equals Mach this

(3, 3).clue: They're the mama & daughter heard here: "Well it's girls' night out..."

(4, 3).clue: This Dutch seat of government doubles as the capital of South Holland province

(5, 3).clue: Donato di Niccolo found fame as a Renaissance sculptor using this name (later taken by a Ninja Turtle)

(6, 3).clue: The "holy" first pope is in this '60s folk trio also including this actress who was "America's Sweetheart"
(6, 3).correct response: Pope Peter, Paul and Mary Pickford

(1, 4).clue: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for" them

(2, 4).clue: 1 square furlong equals this many acres

(3, 4).clue: Her first two (less famous) husbands were musician Toshi Ichiyanagi & filmmaker Tony Cox

(4, 4).clue: It lies on the Danube River, about 135 miles southeast of Vienna

(5, 4).clue: First & last name of the "Garden of Earthly Delights" painter; he took the name from the town of 'S Hertogenbosch

(6, 4).clue: A child's tiny green plastic military figure who fights for money inside a Chinese dessert item

(1, 5).clue: In the book of Revelation it is written, "Behold a pale horse and his name that sat on him was" this

(2, 5).clue: In weight, 1 British stone equals this many pounds

(3, 5).clue: In 2001 Time magazine named this Olympia, Washington female trio America's best rock band

(4, 5).clue: It's alphabetically last among Europe's capital cities

(5, 5).clue: The surname of this "Primavera" painter came from his brother's nickname, which meant "little barrel"

(6, 5).clue: If a marriage held at the point of a firearm advertised added electronic frills, they'd be these

(0, 0).clue: When he moved into the White House, George W. Bush brought some of his over 150 autographed ones of these
